thread.title: Where North and South Korea Meet

author: wsjcom
title: Where North and South Korea Meet
text:
8 COMMENTS Panmunjom has hosted several meetings between North and South Korea. For the past 65 years, the tiny village of Panmunjom in the demilitarized zone has served as a symbol of the division of the Korean Peninsula into North and South.
On Friday, the two sides convened there once again as South Korean President Moon Jae-in, whose parents hailed from the North, hosted North Korea’s third-generation leader, Kim Jong Un, on the South side of Panmunjom, in the first inter-Korean summit in more than a decade .
Here, a look at the historic site and the countries on either side.
Tour the storied location of the 2018 summit. A North Korean leader will cross the Military Demarcation Line for the first time since the Korean War. United Nations forces cross the 38th parallel, the frontier between the two Koreas, in 1950. Photo: Interim Archives/Getty Images Representatives from North and South Korea met in Panmunjom on Nov. 3, 1971. During that meeting, below, the two countries discussed possible family reunions, among other topics. Photo: Klaus Morgenstern/DPA/ZUMA PRESS Photo: Klaus Morgenstern/DPA/ZUMA PRESS Panmunjom is still known as ‘truce village.’ Photo: Bjorn Bergman/ZUMA PRESS A Study in Economic Contrasts Since an armistice agreement between the United Nations, North Korea and China was signed in Panmunjom on July 27, 1953, the two Koreas have traveled starkly divergent paths.
Both countries faced extreme poverty at the end of the Korean War, but the widening gap between their economies today highlights the contrasting fates of their systems.
The capitalist South, backed by the U.S., is now one of the world’s biggest economies, while the communist North’s growth stalled in the 1970s. The country suffered a crippling famine in the 1990s.
South Korea, Asia’s fourth-largest economy, is deeply integrated into global trade networks. North Korea continues to rely on international aid, due in part to the country’s diplomatic and economic isolation .
South Korea’s economy is an export powerhouse, specializing in products such as semiconductors, smartphones and cars. The majority of North Korea’s exports of coal and other natural resources go to its neighbors, China and Russia.
South and North Korean soldiers stand guard at Panmunjom. Photo: LEE JIN-MAN/ASSOCIATED PRESS The Front Line in Discussions The Korean War reached a stalemate in mid-1951 as U.N. forces and North Korean and Chinese troops sought to bring an end to the fighting. The two sides met in Panmunjom to begin hammering out the terms of a cease-fire. Negotiations took two years, hung up on a number of contentious issues, including the exchange of prisoners of war.
